trial_identification.studytitle: Central brain responses of sacral nerve stimulation in patients with faecal incontinence
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A prospective experimental study investigating the impact of sacral nerve stimulation on brain activity in patients with faecal incontinence

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Other diseases of the mouth, teeth, oesophagus, digestive system including liver and colon
Studies of the normal brain and nervous system

interventions.interventions: This is an observational study, the exposure is acquisition of brain images using fMRI. Sacral nerve stimulator is a pacemaker like device implanted in the buttock and connected to leads that are placed in the S3 or S4 foramina percutaneously. fMRI involves acquisition of images whilst providing a visceral stimulus i.e. rectal balloon distension. This is performed at baseline and 6 weeks post device implantation.
interventions.comparator: Patients' baseline measurements will act as the control measurements for each participant

primaryOutcome.outcome: Changes in brain activity with the device switched on, as assessed using functional MRI
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline and 6 weeks post implantation of sacral nerve stimulator

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Changes in resting state brain activity, assessed by fMRI
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline and 6 weeks post implantation of device

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: 1. Age >18 years 2. Predominant symptom: Faecal Incontinence 3. Have no contraindications to MRI 4. Participants already scheduled to be treated by sacral nerve stimulation
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: 1. Non-English speaking 2. Cognitive impairment 3. CI to MRI e.g. claustrophobia 4. Major Psychological Disorders (eg. Major Depression, Major Anxiety, Schizophrenia, Bipolar) 4. Pregnancy 5. Neurological disorders e.g. Spina Bifida, Multiple Sclerosis, Parkinson disease.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Sacral Nerve Stimulation(SNS) has revolutionised the management of urinary and faecal incontinence over the past 20 years. SNS is now embraced worldwide as a first line treatment for patients with urinary and faecal incontinence in whom conservative measures have failed. However, despite extensive experience with the stimulator and research in the field, its mechanism(s) of action remains elusive. Recently it has been suggested that SNS works by changing the way the brain functions by 'restarting' its normal function, akin to 'restarting a computer'. In this study we aim to lend scientific support for this hypothesis by investigating the impact of SNS on brain function using functional MRI (fMRI).
